newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan dollar ends lower, resumes downtrend.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan dollar ends lower, resumes downtrend.

text.p: The Taiwan dollar reversed its early gains and closed lower against its U.S. counterpart on Monday due to widespread expectations of a resumed downtrend on local political concerns, dealers said.

The local unit closed at T$27.819 against one U.S. dollar. It had opened at an intra-day peak of T$27.790, reflecting the greenback's fall overseas against the German mark following the first round of French elections on Sunday.
Turnover through dealers was a light US$149 million.
Dealers said the fall was caused by persistent fund outflows on political concerns over recent anti-government protests in Taiwan and the island's ongoing constitutional reforms.
The concerns have caused the local unit to ease from its long-time T$27.5 support level in the past month.
"Investors continue to think that the Taiwan dollar is locked in a downtrend against the U.S. currency, so profit-taking occurred soon after the initial rise," said one dealer at a foreign bank.
A T$27.79-84 range was seen for Tuesday.
